column4: is it just me, or does ubuntu seem to take up more, and more, and more hard drive space? It used to take up 10 GB, but now it takes up 12. how can i find out which packages I don't need anymore and uninstall them?
are you on edgy?
on edgy, you can do "sudo apt-get autoremove" to remove packages that are not needed anymore. debfoster and orphaner are also possibilities, though you have to take time and care
however, if you have upgraded from an older version, "apt-get autoremove" won't recognize the unneeded packages that were installed on the older version, because there was no such feature then
how do i know what to say yes and no to with debfoster?
you should say "yes" to the packages you explicitely want to keep. i would be careful personally, though
also, personally i'd try orphaner first. it's a bit easier on you, and by default it only looks at *libraries*, not everything... which imho would make it much more error-proof
the other side of the coin obviously being that it'll remove less cruft
orphaner isn't in Synaptic
right, the package name is "deborphan". orphaner is the command for getting a text interface to it
thank
thank you
orphaner is only freeing 144 MB of space, how did ubuntu get so inflated? it used to be 10 GB (which is already a lot) and now it's 12!
i'm sure that a fresh Ubuntu is *way* less than 10gb
my (kubuntu) edgy right now is taking about 4gb... and i have a lot of non-default stuff installed (-dev packages, etc)
did you compile stuff, as well? if so you'd have some/many -dev packages installed. those can take up space
ya i've had to compile a few things
you could try "orphaner --guess-dev" (if that's even the right syntax), that will check for -dev packages as well as libraries
ya that was the right syntax
xserver-xorg-dev might do it
it didn't work
try xlibs-dev then
i'd make it just kdelibs4-dev for starters
